message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ability of cancer cells to invade and migrate away from the original site of insertion suggests that the cells are capable of metastasis. Among the options, only the release of matrix metalloproteinase is directly linked to the process of metastasis. Matrix metalloproteinase enzymes break down extracellular matrix components, allowing cancer cells to move into adjacent tissues and eventually spread to distant sites. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of fibrous tissue capsule are not directly linked to the process of metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Matrix metalloproteinase breaks down extracellular matrix components, which allows cancer cells to break through basement membranes and invade surrounding tissues, facilitating metastasis. Loss of cellular polarity is a hallmark of cancer but is not specific to metastasis. Overexpression of HER2/neu is associated with breast cancer but does not necessarily lead to metastasis. A fibrous tissue capsule may actually inhibit metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ability of neoplastic cells to invade and migrate suggests that they have the ability to break down extracellular matrix and invade tissues, which is the function of matrix metalloproteinases. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of fibrous tissue capsule are not directly related to the ability to metastasize.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ability to invade and migrate away from the original site suggests that these neoplastic cells have the ability to degrade the extracellular matrix, which is mediated by the release of matrix metalloproteinase. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of fibrous tissue capsule are not directly related to the ability to metastasize.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ability of breast cancer cells to invade and migrate away from the original site of insertion suggests that they have the ability to break down extracellular matrix, which is facilitated by the release of matrix metalloproteinases. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of fibrous tissue capsule are not directly related to the ability of cancer cells to metastasize.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The ability to invade and migrate away from the original site of insertion is indicative of metastasis, and the most likely property responsible for this is the release of matrix metalloproteinase, which is involved in invasion and migration through the extracellular matrix. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of a fibrous tissue capsule may be associated with cancer progression but are not directly involved in metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Matrix metalloproteinases are enzymes that are involved in the degradation of extracellular matrix, making it easier for cancer cells to invade and metastasize. Loss of cellular polarity and overexpression of HER2/neu are both associated with cancer development and progression but not specifically with metastasis. A fibrous tissue capsule would actually inhibit invasion and migration of cancer cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Matrix metalloproteinase (MMP) is an enzyme that can degrade the extracellular matrix, allowing cancer cells to invade surrounding tissues and metastasize. Loss of cellular polarity and overexpression of HER2/neu are both associated with breast cancer, but they are not the main factor responsible for metastasis. The presence of a fibrous tissue capsule can actually inhibit metastasis by containing the tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In vitro hematogenous invasion and migration away from the original site of insertion is a property associated with metastasis, and among the options, only release of matrix metalloproteinase has been implicated in promoting tumor metastasis. Loss of cellular polarity, overexpression of HER2/neu, and presence of fibrous tissue capsule are not directly linked to tumor metastasis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only release of matrix metalloproteinase is known to play a crucial role in tumor invasion and metastasis, including breast cancer. Loss of cellular polarity and overexpression of HER2/neu may contribute to the development of breast cancer, but not necessarily metastasis. The presence of a fibrous tissue capsule is actually a protective mechanism that can prevent metastasis.
